overview.title: What are Countable Nouns?
overview.description: [translate: Countable nouns are nouns that can be counted as individual units, with singular and plural forms.] They refer to things you can count one by one.
key_points: Can be used with numbers (one, two, three, etc.)
Use 'a' or 'an' with singular countable nouns
Plural usually formed by adding -s or -es
overview.importance: Mastering countable nouns helps learners describe quantities, make sentences about numbers, and ask questions clearly.

sections.title: Definition and Examples
sections.content: [translate: Countable nouns refer to people, animals, objects, or ideas that can be counted one at a time.] They have both singular and plural forms, and you can use numbers with them.

subsections.subtitle: Singular and Plural Forms
subsections.text: Singular forms use 'a' or 'an.' Plural forms are usually created by adding 's' or 'es' at the end.

sections.title: Using Countable Nouns in Sentences
sections.content: Countable nouns can act as subjects, objects, and complements in sentences. They can be quantified specifically using numbers or quantifiers like 'many' and 'few.'

subsections.subtitle: Quantifiers with Countable Nouns
subsections.text: Use 'many', 'few', 'several', and 'a few' for countable nouns, not 'much' or 'little'.

sections.title: Common Issues and Tips
sections.content: Some nouns may be countable in one sense but uncountable in another. Pay attention to context and meaning.

subsections.subtitle: Context Examples
subsections.text: 'Chicken' can be countable referring to animals and uncountable referring to meat.

grammar_rules.title: Use 'a' or 'an' with singular countable nouns
grammar_rules.description: Singular countable nouns require the indefinite articles 'a' or 'an'.
grammar_rules.tip: Always include articles with singular countable nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Form plurals by adding -s or -es
grammar_rules.description: Plural countable nouns are typically made by adding 's' or 'es' to the singular form.
grammar_rules.tip: Remember special plural forms ending with 'es'.

grammar_rules.title: Use quantifiers like 'many' and 'few' for plural countables
grammar_rules.description: 'Many', 'few', and similar words modify plural countable nouns.

grammar_rules.title: Different meanings in countable and uncountable contexts
grammar_rules.description: Some nouns like 'paper' or 'chicken' can be countable or uncountable depending on meaning and context.
grammar_rules.tip: Pay attention to context to decide usage.

grammar_rules.title: Use plural forms with plural verbs
grammar_rules.description: Plural countable nouns take plural verb forms in sentences.
grammar_rules.tip: Match verb number with noun number.

examples.analysis: 'Cats' is plural of the countable noun 'cat'.

examples.sentence: There are many birds in the sky.
An elephant is a large animal.
A table is in the room.
There are many pens on the desk.
An umbrella is useful in rain.
There are ten students in the class.
A banana is on the table.
There are some oranges in the basket.
She bought a loaf of bread.

complex_sentences.sentence: Five students brought their books to the library.
complex_sentences.analysis: 'Students' and 'books' are countable nouns showing plurality.

complex_sentences.sentence: A dog chased three cats across the yard.
complex_sentences.analysis: 'Dog', 'cats' are countable nouns with singular and plural forms.

complex_sentences.sentence: Many workers completed their tasks early.

common_mistakes.error_type: Omitting articles with singular countable nouns
common_mistakes.explanation: Singular countable nouns need an article.
common_mistakes.tip: Always use 'a' or 'an' with singular countable nouns.

common_mistakes.error_type: Using plural verb with singular nouns
common_mistakes.explanation: Match verb number with noun number.
common_mistakes.tip: Use singular verb for singular nouns and plural verb for plural nouns.

common_mistakes.explanation: 'A' is only for singular countable nouns.
'Information' is uncountable and has no plural.

common_mistakes.error_type: Missing plural form for multiple items
common_mistakes.tip: Always pluralize nouns when counting more than one.
